en.value: go on holiday
This year we want to go on holiday in September.
package holiday
If you want an all-inclusive holiday, choose one of our package holidays.
cruise
To enjoy a romantic trip, I advise you to take a cruise in the Greek Islands.
resort
To forget your stress, it's good for you to go to a resort.
adventure holiday
If you like a lot of excitement, I suggest an adventure holiday.
city break
Paris is a very popular destination for city breaks.
sightseeing
Spain's full of historical monuments, it's perfect for sightseeing.
booking
You need to make a booking quickly because the offer ends soon!
cancelled flight
They've cancelled my flight to Argentina!
delayed flight
I'm late, because my flight was delayed.
lose your suitcase
Maria had to buy clothes, because they lost her suitcase.
badly located
The hotel was very badly located, it was far from the city.
complaint
I would like to make a complaint.
there's no hot water
Excuse me, there's no hot water in my room.
dirty room
A four-star hotel and the room is dirty!
overcrowded
The hotel was overcrowded, there were too many people staying there.
unhelpful staff
Let's book a holiday!
Using the past tense to describe things that go wrong on holiday
At the travel agency
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Where do you fancy [k]going on holiday[/k] this year?
I'm not sure to be honest. Why don't we have a look at a brochure?
I've got one here but it's mainly for [k]city breaks[/k].
A city break is too short, I'd like to go on a [k]cruise[/k]!
You know I don't like cruises, how about a normal [k]package holiday[/k]? I need to relax.
Me too, I've been working very hard recently.
There are some very beautiful [k]resorts[/k] in Greece.
Yes they look nice. Don't forget we'll need to take out travel insurance if we go abroad. Imagine if we lost our suitcase!
Laura
Carl
Select the correct option.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
My worst holidays ever
Hello, I'd like to make a [k]complaint[/k] about a recent stay at your hotel.
Sorry you've had a bad experience, what was the problem?
First of all, the staff were very [k]unhelpful[/k] when we first arrived.
I understand that you were late arriving to the hotel. Is that right?
Yes but only because our flight was [k]delayed[/k]! And we [k]lost our suitcase[/k]!
OK, I will speak to the manager about that for you.
Also, we had a [k]dirty room[/k] and there was [k]no hot water[/k] for 3 days.
We have now fixed the problem and we would like to compensate you for this problem by offering you a free night at the hotel.
Paul
Hotel receptionist
Describe your worst holiday ever.
My worst holiday ever was to Morocco in 2014. When I arrived at the hotel they didn't have a room for me. I had made a booking but they didn't have it in the system!
Grammar: Past perfect
The sentence links two past actions.
I had made a booking but they didn't have it in the system.
True or false?
I made a sandwich with all the food in the fridge.
My friend had called before, so they knew we were coming.
To look backwards from a past event and link it to another event further in the past we can use the Past Perfect tense.
My friend had called before, so they knew we were coming.
The sentence uses the Past Perfect tense.
I bought the ingredients and then cooked for the whole day.
I had heated the oven so it was already hot.
We finished the food before all the guests had arrived.

We can link past events with linking words (e.g with 'then', 'before', 'after that' etc.) or we can use the past perfect tense. This tense tells us which action happened first and shows a connection between two past actions.

I had heated the oven so it was already hot.
We finished the food before all the guests had arrived.
[k]Suddenly[/k] [k]I realised[/k] [k]I had left my suitcase[/k] [k]at the airport.[/k]
[k]She had already[/k] [k]left the party[/k] [k]when[/k] [k]I arrived.[/k]
[k]The doors[/k] [k]had been left open[/k] [k]and[/k] [k]lots of flies[/k] [k]came in.[/k]
The Past Perfect tense is formed with had + past participle. The earlier action takes the Past Perfect tense and the later action is usually in Past Simple tense:
They had bought the drinks (first action), when we got there. (later action)
[k]There had been[/k] [k]a big party[/k] [k]and the house[/k] [k]was a mess.[/k]
[k]She'd[/k] [k]bought a house[/k] [k]and[/k] [k]rented out[/k] [k]the rooms.[/k]
[k]They[/k] [k]had[/k] [k]just discovered[/k] [k]the new restaurant[/k] [k]and[/k] [k]went there[/k] [k]every week.[/k]
The auxiliary verb had is often contracted when used with pronouns and in negative sentences:

She had been = She'd been
We had not seen = We hadn't seen
They [k]had never been[/k] on a cruise before, and they [k]were[/k] very excited.
never went
had been
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
It [k]was[/k] the best holiday they'd ever [k]been[/k] on.
is
go
[k]They'd[/k] been swimming and [k]were[/k] standing on the beach.
They've
was
We [k]hadn't had[/k] showers because there [k]wasn't[/k] any hot water.
don't have
won't be
Past Perfect tense - not clean
The hotel was terrible and they [k]had not cleaned|hadn't cleaned[/k] the rooms.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Past Perfect tense - pack
I [k]had packed[/k] my suitcase badly and didn't have the right clothes.
Past Perfect Tense - never be
I [k]had never been|had never gone[/k] to a city of that size, and I felt quite nervous.
Past Perfect tense - be cancelled
Our flight [k]had been cancelled|had been canceled[/k] so we had to wait at the airport.
Grammar: Verb patterns II
The sentence talks about an action that was repeated in the past.
I started working for the company six years ago.
We used to go to the South of France on holiday.
When we lived near the sea she would swim every evening.
We use used to + infinitive and would + infinitive to talk about repeated actions and habits in the past.

We used to go to the South of France on holiday.
When we lived near the sea she would swim every evening.
We only use 'would' after the situation has been established with Past Simple or 'used to'.
I used to live in a village in France. I would cycle to work every day.
The sentence shows a difference between the past and the present.
I used to smoke but I quit two years ago.
I started going to the gym last year and I go about twice a week.
We didn't use to eat healthy food, but we realised how important it is.
Used to shows a contrast between past and present situations:

I used to walk to work. = but I don't any more.
We didn't use to get on very well. = but we get on well now.
The sentence talk about past states, not actions.
We used to live by the sea.
We would go swimming every evening after work.
I would like to go to the cinema.
We can use used to to talk about past states that are different to the present.
We used to live by the sea.
would is only used to talk about repeated actions, not states.
[k]My friend[/k] [k]used[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]live[/k] [k]on this street.[/k]
[k]We[/k] [k]didn't[/k] [k]use[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]like each other,[/k] [k]but[/k] [k]we do now.[/k]
[k]Did[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]use[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]go to school together?[/k]

In positive sentences we use 'used to'. For negatives and questions we use the auxiliary verb 'did' with 'use to'.
The pronunciation for 'used to' and 'use to' is the same. For negative uses of 'would' we use 'would not' or 'wouldn't'.
I used to live in Spain. I didn't use to do much exercise. I would go there early in the morning. There wouldn't be anyone else in the pool.
Note: be/get used to shows familiarity with something.
My new job was hard, but I've got used to it now. = now I am more familiar with the job.
When we were young we [k]would[/k] walk to school together.
will
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I [k]used to[/k] really enjoy this show.
would
We used to be friends, but we [k]don't talk[/k] now.
talk
It was a challenge at first, but [k]I'm used to it[/k] now.
I used to it
They [k]didn't use to[/k] open in the evenings.
didn't used to
Where [k]did you use to[/k] live?
you used to
used to / would - not drink
I [k]didn't use to drink|wouldn't drink|would not drink[/k] enough water when I was younger.
used to / would - play
She [k]used to play|would play[/k] tennis every night.
used to / would - do
When we were young we [k]would do|used to do[/k] our homework together.
used to - I play
[k]I used to play[/k] football at school
used to - be
She [k]used to be[/k] much happier.
